front.div:
In computer science and information science, an
ontology is a formal representation of the knowledge
by a set of concepts within a domain and the
relationships between those concepts. It is used to
reason about the properties of that domain, and may
be used to describe the domain.
In theory, an ontology is a "formal, explicit
specification of a shared conceptualisation".
[1] An
ontology provides a shared vocabulary, which can be
used to model a domain — that is, the type of objects
and/or concepts that exist, and their properties and
relations.
[2]
Ontologies are used in artificial intelligence, the Semantic Web, systems engineering, software engineering,
biomedical informatics, library science, enterprise bookmarking, and information architecture as a form of
knowledge representation about the world or some part of it. The creation of domain ontologies is also
fundamental to the definition and use of an enterprise architecture framework.
